column4: Drug distributors lose bid to escape West Virginia opioid lawsuit
column5: The nation’s “Big Three” leading drug distributors have failed to escape a lawsuit by the city of Huntington, West Virginia, and its county seeking to hold them liable for harms caused by the opioid epidemic.
column6: U.S. District Judge David Faber in Huntington on Wednesday denied a motion by Cardinal Health Inc, McKesson Corp and AmerisourceBergen for summary judgment, finding that Huntington and Cabell County had standing to pursue a public nuisance claim against them. The order clears the way for a trial to begin in May.
column7: To read the full story on Westlaw Today, click here: bit.ly/31BPQvB

column4: Cardinal Health to sell Cordis medical device business in $1 billion deal
column5: (Reuters) - Cardinal Health Inc will sell its Cordis medical device business to private equity firm Hellman & Friedman in a deal valued at about $1 billion, the drug distributor said on Friday.
column6: The sale of the unit acquired in 2015 from Johnson & Johnson for $1.9 billion comes as drug distributors look to slim down after a rapid pace of consolidation.
column7: Rival AmerisourceBergen Corp last year decided to shut down its compounding pharmacy business, PharMEDium, after struggling with regulatory hurdles and losses.
column8: “This is the latest example of the drug wholesalers unwinding assets snatched up as the industry looked to consolidate over the past 5 years, with the common trend being buying high and selling lower,” Raymond James analyst Alex Ruscher said of the Cordis deal.
column9: The unit, which makes medical devices such as catheters, stents, generates annual revenue of around $780 million and as of Feb. 1 was facing nearly 404 lawsuits related to its vena cava filters used for treating blocked arteries in lungs.
column10: While most assets and liabilities associated with the Cordis business will be transferred to Hellman & Friedman, Cardinal Health will retain full authority for lawsuits related to inferior vena cava filters in the United States and Canada, as well as liability associated with these matters, the company said.
column11: Cardinal Health expects a pre-tax loss of up to $120 million in the third quarter of its fiscal year 2021 after the deal closes.
column12: “These drug distributors have made really bad acquisitions, and this Cordis was one of them...,” Morning Star analyst Soo Romanoff told Reuters. “(Cardinal) is just monetizing it because there are no synergies that they are getting from this business.”
column13: The transaction is expected to close in the first half of Cardinal Health’s fiscal year 2022.
column14: The company’s shares were up 2.3% at $57.04 in late morning trading.

column4: Cardinal Health to sell medical device business in deal valued at $1 bln
column5: March 12 (Reuters) - Drug distributor Cardinal Health Inc said on Friday it would sell its Cordis medical device business to private equity firm Hellman & Friedman in a deal valued at about $1 billion. (Reporting by Manas Mishra in Bengaluru; Editing by Sriraj Kalluvila)

column4: Robbins Geller picked to lead investor case against Cardinal Health
column5: Robbins Geller Rudman & Dowd has beat out two other top plaintiffs firms for the job of lead counsel in a proposed class action alleging Cardinal Health Inc misled investors about problems at a medical device maker it bought.
column6: U.S. District Judge Edmund Sargus in Columbus, Ohio, on Friday picked the firm over rivals Bernstein Litowitz Berger & Grossmann and Block & Leviton after finding Robbins Geller’s client, 1199 SEIU Health Care Employees Pension System, had the largest financial interest in the case--$2.1 million in claimed stock losses.

column4: IN BRIEF: Arent Fox hires Cardinal Health's in-house IP counsel
column5: The top in-house intellectual property lawyer at drug wholesaler and medical supplier Cardinal Health Inc has moved to Arent Fox, the law firm said on Tuesday.
column6: Daniel Stelter, who was at Dublin, Ohio-based Cardinal Health for 13 years, has joined Arent Fox as a San Francisco-based counsel in its intellectual property practice group.

column4: Cardinal Health Inc wins $2.25 billion U.S. defense contract: Pentagon
column5: WASHINGTON (Reuters) - Cardinal Health 200 LLC, a unit of Cardinal Health Inc CAH.N, has been awarded a maximum $2.25 billion modification for a contract with the Defense Logistics Agency for ordering and distribution of medical surgical supplies, the Pentagon said on Thursday.

column4: Cardinal Health top lawyer's pay nears $3 mln as opioid suits pile up
column5: Cardinal Health Inc.’s top in-house lawyer’s compensation for 2019 totaled nearly $3 million, according to a proxy the drug distributor has filed with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission.
column6: The Dublin, Ohio-based company’s chief legal and compliance officer Jessica Mayer earned a total of more than $2.96 million for the company’s fiscal year ended June 30, according to a Friday filing.

column4: Cardinal Health warns ongoing opioid-related lawsuits to hit business
column5: (Reuters) - Drug distributor Cardinal Health Inc warned on Tuesday that its business could be hurt as it defends itself against several opioid-related lawsuits.
column6: Several pharmaceutical wholesale distributors, including Cardinal, have been named as defendants in about 2,500 lawsuits for the distribution of prescription opioid pain medications. These lawsuits have been filed in various federal, state, and other courts by a variety of plaintiffs.
column7: Cardinal said in a filing it expects to be named as a defendant in additional lawsuits.
column8: Pharmaceutical manufacturers and distributors have been in part blamed for the U.S. opioid crisis, accused of deceptively marketing opioids in ways that downplayed their risks.
column9: AmerisourceBergen Corp and McKesson Corp are also facing similar lawsuits.
column10: Cardinal said it was vigorously defending itself in all opioid-related matters, but is unable to predict their outcome or estimate a range of reasonably possible losses. (bit.ly/2KVe5ME)
column11: Cardinal said that ongoing negative publicity could hurt the its reputation or results of operations.
column12: Opioids were involved in 400,000 overdose deaths from 1999 to 2017, according to the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
column13: On Tuesday, drugmakers Endo International Plc and Allergan Plc agreed to pay $15 million to avoid going to trial in October in a landmark opioid-related case by two Ohio counties.
column14: Earlier this month, Bloomberg News reported that McKesson, Cardinal Health and AmerisourceBergen had proposed paying a $10 billion settlement for claims that they played a part in the U.S. opioid epidemic.

column4: Cardinal Health says opioid-related lawsuits to hurt business
column5: Aug 20 (Reuters) - Drug distributor Cardinal Health Inc warned on Tuesday that its business could take a hit as it defends itself against a host of opioid-related lawsuits.
column6: Cardinal is among the drug makers and distributors that are facing lawsuits for allegedly fuelling the opioid crisis.
column7: The company said it was vigorously defending itself in all opioid-related matters, but is unable to predict their outcome or estimate a range of reasonably possible losses.

column4: U.S. Drug distributors propose $10 billion to end state lawsuits over opioids: Bloomberg
column5: (Reuters) - Drug wholesalers AmerisourceBergen Corp ABC.N, McKesson Corp MCK.N and Cardinal Health Inc CAH.N have proposed a $10 billion settlement for claims that they played a part in the U.S. opioid epidemic, Bloomberg reported on Tuesday, citing people familiar with negotiations.
column6: Hundreds of lawsuits by states and cities have been filed nationally accusing drugmakers of deceptively marketing opioids and distributors such as AmerisourceBergen Corp, Cardinal Health Inc and McKesson Corp of ignoring suspicious orders.
column7: Shares of AmerisourceBergen, McKesson and Cardinal Health were down about 5%.
column8: The National Association of Attorneys General, negotiating on behalf of more than 35 states, countered with a demand for $45 billion to cover costs, according to the Bloomberg report.
column9: “We regularly engage with the state attorneys general, but the company has made no settlement offers,” McKesson said in a statement.
column10: Cardinal Health and AmerisourceBergen did not immediately respond to Reuters’ request for comment.

column4: Cardinal Health must turn over suspicious-drug audit in opioid MDL
column5: Cardinal Health Inc has lost a bid to avoid turning over the results of a 2008 audit of its system for identifying suspicious drug orders to lawyers for two Ohio counties who claim the drug wholesale distributor helped fuel the opioid epidemic.
column6: A special master appointed to oversee discovery disputes in the federal multidistrict opioid litigation in Cleveland on Sunday rejected Cardinal’s arguments that the audit was protected by attorney-client privilege.

column4: UPDATE 1-Drug distributor Cardinal's profit beats on pharma unit strength
column5: (Adds details on quarter, background on Cordis unit)
column6: Aug 6 (Reuters) - U.S. drug distributor Cardinal Health Inc beat analyst estimates for adjusted fourth-quarter profit on Monday, supported by higher sales in its pharmaceutical and medical devices businesses.
column7: The company has been plagued with issues at its Cordis medical device unit, which it bought for $1.9 billion in 2015 from Johnson & Johnson. The company had missed quarterly profit expectations in May due to inventory and cost issues at the unit.
column8: Cardinal reported a fourth-quarter loss compared to a year-ago profit, as it took an asset-impairment charge of $1.35 billion primarily related to the unit’s performance.
column9: The company also issued forecast for fiscal year 2019 and said it expects adjusted earnings from continuing operations of $4.90 to $5.15 per share.
column10: Net loss attributable to the company was $1.17 billion, or $3.76 per share, in the fourth quarter ended June 30, compared to a profit of $274 million, or 86 cents per share, a year earlier.
column11: Excluding items, the company earned $1.01 per share, beating analysts’ expectations of 93 cents, as per Thomson Reuters I/B/E/S.
column12: Revenue rose 7.2 percent to $35.35 billion. (Reporting by Anuron Kumar Mitra and Tamara Mathias in Bengaluru; Editing by Shounak Dasgupta)

column4: Cardinal Health posts fourth-quarter loss
column5: Aug 6 (Reuters) - Cardinal Health Inc reported a fourth-quarter loss compared to a year-ago profit, as the U.S. drug distributor was hit by an asset-impairment charge of $1.35 billion.
column6: Net loss attributable to the company was $1.17 billion, or $3.76 per share, in the quarter, compared to a profit of $274 million, or 86 cents per share, a year earlier.
column7: Revenue rose to $35.35 billion from $32.97 billion. (Reporting by Anuron Kumar Mitra and Tamara Mathias in Bengaluru; Editing by Shounak Dasgupta)

column4: Cardinal Health misses profit on Cordis woes, shares fall
column5: (Reuters) - Cardinal Health Inc's CAH.N quarterly profit missed analysts' expectations as inventory and cost issues hurt its Cordis medical device unit, and the U.S. drug distributor said it saw prices of generic drugs fall more than expected.
column6: The company's shares fell 18.8 percent to touch a more than 4-and-a-half year low of $52.93, and Cardinal's commentary on generic drug prices dragged down rivals McKesson Corp MCK.N and AmerisourceBergen Corp ABC.N.
column7: “We recognize that today’s results did not meet your expectations or ours,” Chief Executive Officer Michael Kaufmann said on a conference call.
column8: The company highlighted ongoing operational difficulties regarding inventory at its Cordis business, which it bought for $1.9 billion in 2015 from Johnson & Johnson JNJ.N to expand its medical device offerings and "build an ex-U.S. infrastructure".
column9: “Granted, building of infrastructure has been more expensive than we thought, it hasn’t gone as well as we thought,” Kaufmann said.
column10: The company said it took a large inventory write-off in the third quarter, as it struggled to sell its medical devices before their expiration dates. The Cordis business includes catheters and stents and other equipment used in cardiology and endovascular procedures.
column11: Cardinal Health said on the conference call it expects Cordis will be on “a path to profitable growth” by the end of 2019.
column12: Cardinal also said that a fall in generic drug prices moderated sequentially and year-over-year, but not to the extent it had previously estimated.
column13: Analysts have noted that even though stubbornly low, generic drug prices continue to pose a headwind to drug distributors, the rate at which the prices of generic drugs are falling seems to be stabilizing.
column14: Contributions from the company's Red Oak joint venture with CVS Health Corp CVS.N were not enough to counter the low prices, Cardinal said.
column15: Segment profit at the company’s pharmaceutical division, which distributes generic drugs, fell 3 percent to $596 million. However, sales climbed 5 percent to $29.7 billion, surpassing consensus estimates.
column16: Excluding items, Cardinal earned $1.39 per share. Analysts were expecting earnings of $1.51 per share, according to Thomson Reuters I/B/E/S.
column17: The company cut its fiscal 2018 adjusted earnings forecast to $4.85-$4.95 per share from $5.25-$5.50 per share, reflecting a negative tax rate and Cordis’s performance.
column18: Net earnings attributable to the company fell 33 percent to $255 million, or $0.81 per share, in the quarter.

column4: Drug distributor Cardinal Health's quarterly profit falls 33 pct
column5: May 3 (Reuters) - U.S. drug distributor Cardinal Health Inc posted a 33 percent fall in quarterly profit on Thursday, hurt by a change in the company’s effective tax rate primarily associated with its Cordis business.
column6: Net earnings attributable to the company fell to $255 million, or $0.81 per share, in the third quarter, from $381 million, or $1.20 per share, a year earlier.
column7: Revenue rose 5.7 percent to $33.63 billion. (Reporting by Manas Mishra in Bengaluru; Editing by Amrutha Gayathri)
